Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Expectation2: Review and analyze legal documents and contracts
Situation2: A client has sent a standard contract for a routine service engagement that is not due back for quite some time.
Story: I sat at my desk, the contract from my client open on my laptop, its legal jargon blurring together as my phone buzzed again. My sister’s name flashed on the screen. She’d just called me an hour ago, her voice trembling as she told me about the news—something so heavy, I could hear her trying not to cry. I promised I’d call her back soon, but now, staring at the contract, I felt torn. As a lawyer, I knew this document wasn’t urgent, but I also knew my client expected thoroughness and professionalism, even for routine matters. Yet, as a sibling, I was supposed to be there for my sister, to listen, to comfort her, especially now. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my attention in different ways. My mind raced, guilt gnawing at me for even hesitating. I wanted to be the reliable lawyer my client trusted, but more than anything, I wanted to be the supportive sibling my sister needed. My hand hovered over the phone, heart pounding, caught between duty and love, unsure which role to answer first.
